text: Information retrieval is the process of obtaining information system resources that are relevant to an information need from a collection of those resources.
title: Introduction to Information Retrieval

text: Boolean retrieval is one of the simplest forms of information retrieval. It uses Boolean operators AND, OR, and NOT to combine query terms.
title: Boolean Retrieval Model

text: The vector space model represents documents and queries as vectors in a high-dimensional space. Similarity is measured using cosine similarity.
title: Vector Space Model

text: An inverted index is a data structure that maps terms to the documents containing them. It enables fast retrieval of documents matching query terms.
title: Inverted Index Data Structure

text: Positional indexing extends the inverted index by storing the positions of terms within documents. This enables phrase queries and proximity searches.
title: Positional Index

text: TF-IDF weighting is a numerical statistic that reflects how important a word is to a document in a collection. TF stands for term frequency and IDF for inverse document frequency.
title: TF-IDF Weighting Scheme

text: Precision and recall are fundamental metrics for evaluating information retrieval systems. Precision measures the fraction of retrieved documents that are relevant.
title: Evaluation Metrics: Precision and Recall

text: Query expansion is a technique to improve retrieval effectiveness by reformulating the original query. It can use relevance feedback or query term synonyms.
title: Query Expansion Techniques

text: Clustering algorithms group similar documents together. Common algorithms include K-means clustering and hierarchical clustering methods.
title: Document Clustering

text: Text summarization aims to produce a concise summary of a document while preserving its key information. Methods include extractive and abstractive summarization.
title: Automatic Text Summarization

text: The melamine milk scandal involved contaminated infant formula and dairy products. The scandal affected information retrieval systems tracking food safety.
title: Case Study: Melamine Scandal

text: Chinese information retrieval faces unique challenges including word segmentation, character encoding, and phonetic similarity matching using systems like CSoundex.
title: Chinese IR Challenges

text: Relevance feedback allows users to refine search results by indicating which documents are relevant. The Rocchio algorithm is a classic relevance feedback method.
title: Relevance Feedback and Rocchio

text: Web search engines like Google use sophisticated ranking algorithms including PageRank to determine the relevance and importance of web pages.
title: Web Search and PageRank

text: Natural language processing techniques are increasingly important in modern information retrieval systems. They help understand user intent and document semantics.
title: NLP in Information Retrieval
